q: What is the primary purpose of a JOIN in SQL?
o: To combine rows from two or more tables, based on a related column between them

q: Which JOIN returns records that have matching values in both tables?
Which JOIN returns all records from the left table, and the matched records from the right table?
What happens in a LEFT JOIN if there is no match in the right table?
o: The result is NULL on the right side

q: Which JOIN returns all records from the right table, and the matched records from the left table?
Which JOIN returns all records when there is a match in either left or right table?

o: A join that produces the Cartesian product of the two tables (all combinations)

q: If Table A has 10 rows and Table B has 5 rows, how many rows will a CROSS JOIN return?

o: A regular join where a table is joined with itself

q: Which keyword is optional in 'INNER JOIN'?
Is 'LEFT OUTER JOIN' same as 'LEFT JOIN'?
Which clause is used to specify the join condition?
Can you use WHERE clause to filter results after a JOIN?

o: A join based on all columns in two tables that have the same name

q: In a Natural Join, do you specify the ON clause?
How to join three tables A, B, and C?
o: FROM A JOIN B ON ... JOIN C ON ...
A join containing an equality operator (=)
A join condition using operators other than equal (e.g. <, >, BETWEEN)

q: Can you join on multiple columns?
o: Yes, using AND in the ON clause

q: What happens if join columns have different data types?
o: Implicit conversion may occur (performance risk) or execution fails if incompatible

q: What is the result of joining on NULL values?
How to get rows from Table A that are NOT in Table B?
o: LEFT JOIN ... WHERE B.ID IS NULL

q: What is the 'USING' clause in JOINs (MySQL/Postgres)?
o: Shorthand for ON when columns have same names (USING(id))

q: What is a 'Merge Join' in execution plans?
o: Algorithm requiring both inputs to be sorted on join keys; highly efficient

q: What is a 'Hash Join' in execution plans?
o: Algorithm building a hash table in memory for one input (Build) and probing with other (Probe)

q: What is a 'Nested Loop Join' in execution plans?
o: For each row in outer table, scan inner table for matches (good for small inputs)

q: Which join algorithm needs lots of memory for the Build phase?
Which join algorithm requires sorted inputs?
Which join algorithm is best for very large unsorted datasets?
Which join algorithm is typically fastest for simple Key Lookups (small number of rows)?

o: Returns rows from one table where one or more matches exist in another (EXISTS usage)
Returns rows from one table where NO match exists in another (NOT EXISTS)

q: Can you join a table with a View?
Can you join a table with a Subquery (Derived Table)?
Does the order of tables in INNER JOIN matter for results?
Does the order of tables in LEFT JOIN matter for results?
o: Yes, A LEFT JOIN B is different from B LEFT JOIN A

q: Can you join across different databases on the same server?
Can you join across different servers?

o: General term for a join with any condition (usually non-equality)

q: How to optimize a JOIN performance?
o: Index the join columns (Foreign Keys, Primary Keys)

q: What happens if you forget the ON clause in older syntax (comma syntax)?
o: It becomes a CROSS JOIN (Cartesian Product)

q: Which is preferred: ANSI SQL-92 (JOIN keyword) or SQL-89 (Comma syntax)?
o: ANSI SQL-92 (Explicit JOIN syntax is clearer and safer)
Allows the right side to reference columns from the left side (like a loop)
Unpivoting data, splitting strings, or invoking a TVF for each row

q: Can FULL OUTER JOIN be simulated in MySQL (which lacks it)?
o: Yes, using LEFT JOIN UNION RIGHT JOIN
Joining on multiple columns (Col1 = Col1 AND Col2 = Col2)

q: In a self-join, what is mandatory?
o: Table Aliases to distinguish the two instances
Instruction to force a specific join algorithm (e.g. INNER LOOP JOIN)

q: Should you routinely use JOIN Hints?
o: No, limits optimizer's flexibility; only for troubleshooting or specific fixes
The set of all possible pairs of rows from two tables (Row count A * Row count B)
Index (Oracle) that stores the rowids of a fact table corresponding to values in a dimension table

If T1 has (1,2) and T2 has (1,3), what does LEFT JOIN produce?

o: Yes, under specific conditions (usually restricted to one base table)
Joining Table A to B, then B to C, then C to D...

o: No, filtering on aggregates belongs in HAVING

Execution plan shape where joins are performed in parallel subtrees rather than deep left/right linear trees

q: What is 'Broadcast Move' in distributed joins (MPP)?
o: Copying a small table to all nodes to join with a distributed large table

q: What is 'Shuffle Move' in distributed joins?
o: Redistributing data from both tables on the join key so matching keys end up on same node
Optimize join where both tables are partitioned on the join key (join partition 1 to partition 1, etc.)

q: Can a LEFT JOIN increase the number of rows from the left table?
o: Yes, if the join key in the right table is not unique (1-to-many relationship)

o: Returns all left rows with NULLs for right columns

q: Can you JOIN on calculated columns?

o: Generally No, prevents index seek (SARGability issue)

q: How to fix poor performance of join on calculated columns?
o: Persist calculation in a computed column and index it

q: What is the maximum number of tables in a JOIN?
o: Depends on implementation (e.g. 256 in SQL Server), but typically limited by complexity/memory

q: Why prefer Explicit Join over Implicit?
o: Separates join logic from filter logic; avoids accidental cross joins; standard compliance

q: What is the limit of recursion in SQL Server?

q: What is the 'NULL safe equality' operator in MySQL?
How to achieve NULL safe join in SQL Server?
o: ON (a.col = b.col OR (a.col IS NULL AND b.col IS NULL))

q: Can triggers fire on JOIN views?
o: Only INSTEAD OF triggers are typically supported on views

q: What describes 'Non-Matching' rows in INNER JOIN?
o: Rows that are discarded because they don't satisfy the ON condition

q: What is the result of 'A LEFT JOIN B' if A is empty?
What is the result of 'A RIGHT JOIN B' if A is empty?
o: All rows from B (with NULLs for A columns)

q: What happens if you join Many-to-Many directly without bridge?

q: How to traverse a Self-Referencing table recursively?

q: What does 'Anti-Semi Join' return in plan?
o: Rows that fail the match (NOT EXISTS)

q: Can 'INTERSECT' be implemented as a Join?
o: Yes, Inner Join on all columns

q: Can 'EXCEPT' be implemented as a Join?
o: Yes, Left Join ... WHERE right IS NULL

q: Which is generally faster: EXISTS or IN (for subquery)?
o: Modern optimizers often treat them identically, but EXISTS handles NULLs more intuitively

q: What is 'Probe Residual' in Hash Join?
o: Additional predicate checking on rows that passed the initial hash mach

q: What is 'Build Input' in Hash Join?
o: The smaller input usually chosen to build the hash table

q: What is 'Probe Input' in Hash Join?
o: The larger input that streams through and probes the hash table

q: What is 'Memory Grant' importance for Hash Join?
o: Crucial; if insufficient, it spills to TempDB (Hash Spill), killing performance
A single dimension table joined multiple times for different purposes (e.g. OrderDate, ShipDate from DateDim)

q: How to handle Role-Playing Dimension in SQL?
o: Use aliases for each join instance (e.g. JOIN DateDim AS OrderDate ... JOIN DateDim AS ShipDate ...)

q: What is 'Cross Database Join' security requirement?
o: Login must be mapped to users in both databases with SELECT permission

o: Bushy allows parallel joins of sub-trees; Left Deep joins one table at a time linearly

q: Difference between Temp Table and Table Variable in JOIN?
o: Temp Tables have statistics (better plans); Table Variables don't (often estimate 1 row)

q: When to prefer Table Variable in Join?
o: Very small datasets or code simplicity required (no stats overhead)

q: When to prefer Temp Table in Join?
o: Large datasets where statistics and indexes are needed for good plan

Builds the spool table on demand (as rows are asked for)
Reads all rows from input and builds spool before passing any (Blocking)

Performs a scalar computation (expression evaluation) in the stream

Builds hash table to group rows (unsorted input, memory intensive)

Row moved to another page (heap) leaving a pointer behind (Heap fragmentation)

q: Why does Optimizer choose Scan over Lookups for large row counts?
o: Random I/O of Lookups becomes more expensive than Sequential I/O of Scan

q: What is result of 'DISABLE' lock escalation?

q: Which Isolation Level is default in SQL Server?

Dirty Reads (reading data that gets rolled back)
Reads only committed data (Shared locks held during read operation)

Highest level; Emulates serial execution using Range Locks (prevents Phantoms)

Process that flushes dirty pages to disk to ensure durability (regardless of memory pressure)
Page in memory modified but not yet written to disk
Page in memory that matches disk version (can be dropped instantly)
Database setting controlling Indirect Checkpoint frequency (seconds)
Background task removing ghost records (physically deleting rows marked for delete)
Removing old row versions from TempDB that are no longer needed by any snapshot transaction
Growth is expensive (zero initialization); Shrink causes fragmentation (VLFs)
Fixed size (e.g. 512MB/1GB) rather than percentage (avoids tiny or massive growths)
Physical structural damage to pages/extents (Disk rot, bad RAM, firmware bugs)
Checks physical and logical consistency of database pages, indexes, and constraints
Weekly or Daily (depending on database size and maintenance window)
Last resort checkdb option; fixes corruption by deleting invalid data
Max tolerable amount of data loss measured in time (e.g. 15 mins)
Target time to restore service after failure (e.g. 4 hours)
Final log backup taken after a failure (if log is accessible) to capture data up to point of failure
Feature where SQL calculates checksum on write and verifies on read (detects disk corruption)
Older mechanism checking if 8KB page was partially written (sector mismatch)
Compressing backup stream; saves space and time (at cost of CPU)
Writing backup to multiple files/disks simultaneously (Increases throughput)
Writing backup to 2-4 identical locations for redundancy
Backing up log only when it has grown or minimal time passed (Dynamic)
Job scheduling service for SQL Server (Backups, Maintenance, ETL)
Contact (Email/Pager) to notify when job fails
Response to a specific event or error condition (e.g. Severity 19 error)
Automating jobs across multiple servers (MSX/TSX) from a master
SSIS package created via wizard for routine tasks (CheckDB, Reindex, Backup)

q: Why prefer custom scripts (Ola Hallengren) over Maintenance Plans?
o: More intelligence (e.g. only reorganize if frag > X), better logging, flexibility
Subsystem for sending emails from SQL Server (SMTP)
Granting users only the minimum permissions necessary
Poorly written .NET assemblies can destabilize server or leak memory (Strict security recommended)
Allows DB context to escape to server level (Risk if DB owner is not trusted)
Allows views/procs to access objects in OTHER databases without permission check (Security Risk)
Allows logins without specific database user to connect (Should usually be disabled)
Built-in System Administrator (God mode); often targeted by attacks
Rename it, Disable it, or give it a complex password; Do not use for app connection
Database user whose login no longer exists on the server (SID mismatch)
sp_change_users_login 'Auto_Fix' (Deprecated) or ALTER USER ... WITH LOGIN
User authenticated at database level (No Login required on master)
Role activated by password that overrides user permissions (used by apps)
Signing procs with a certificate to grant permissions via the cert (Safest way to elevate privileges)
Extending buffer pool to SSD file (caching clean pages only)
Wait for query memory grant (indicates memory pressure)
Wait for a worker thread to pick up request (Worker Starvation - Critical)
Check for tight loops in code or hardware issues (dump analysis)
Internal circular buffer storing diagnostic info (exceptions, memory events) for CSS
DLL called from SQL (Deprecated, replaced by CLR)
Allows SQL to instantiate COM objects (Security risk, Avoid)
View uniting tables from different servers (Federation)
Horizontal partitioning of data across multiple independent databases/instances
Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance (SQL Server traditionally favors CA or CP depending on config)
Basically Available, Soft state, Eventual consistency
Using multiple data storage technologies (SQL, NoSQL, Cache) for different parts of app
Data processing architecture using both Batch layer (comprehensive) and Speed layer (real-time)
Architecture processing everything as a stream (removing batch layer)
Lake: Raw data in native format (Schema-on-Read); Warehouse: Structured, curated data (Schema-on-Write)
Decentralized data architecture organizing data by domain (Data as a Product)
Integrated layer connecting data processes/tools/metadata across hybrid cloud
The golden record chosen to represent a group of duplicates
Finding strings that match a pattern approximately (Levenshtein distance, Jaro-Winkler)
Phonetic algorithm for indexing names by sound (English)
Configurable duration (default 3 days) before change data is cleaned up
Configurable (Finite or Infinite) retention policy for history table
Migrates cold data transparently to Azure while keeping hot data on-prem
Tagging columns with sensitivity labels (GDPR compliance)
Supplementary Characters (Support for Unicode surrogate pairs, emojis)
Sorts/Compares based on code point values (Fastest, case-sensitive, exact)
Settings (MAXDOP, CE, Parameter Sniffing) applied per DB instead of instance
Metrics tracking what threads are waiting on (Key to performance tuning)
Time spent in Runnable queue waiting for CPU *after* resource was available
Total Wait - Signal Wait (Time actually waiting for the resource)
Architecture using optimistic concurrency and interlocked operations (no locks/latches)
Code name for In-Memory OLTP engine
Rowgroup has reached 1 million rows and is ready for compression
Rowgroup has been compressed and this delta store is marked for removal
Create Clustered Index (or ALTER TABLE REBUILD in newer versions)
Can prevent index seek if priority of data types forces column conversion
Can index deterministic, precise computed columns
Computed value stored physically (allows indexing even if non-precise)
Column optimized for NULL storage (Zero space for NULLs, overhead for values)
XML representation of all sparse columns in a table
Automatic process triggered by checkpoint to delete unlinked files
Writing intermediate results to disk because memory grant insufficiency

q: How does 'Memory Grant Feedback' fix spills?
o: Increases memory grant for subsequent executions
Improving query performance by learning from runtime statistics (feedback loop)
Caching query results in the control node for instant replay
Pre-computed joins/aggregations stored physically and AUTO-MATCHED by optimizer
